definitions.definition: to have a particular idea or opinion about something/somebody; to believe something
definitions.sensetop: think (that)…it is thought that…think somethingthink something about somethingthink something of somethingthink sothink somebody/something + adj.think somebody/something + nounbe thought to be somebody/somethingthink of somebody/something as somebody/something

examples.text: Do you **really think** (that) he'll win?
I thought I heard a scream.
I didn't think people were allowed to park here.
**Am I right in thinking** that you used to live here?
I think this is their house, but I'm not sure.
He ought to resign, I think.
That's my opinion, but you might **think otherwise** *(= have a different opinion)*.
We'll need about 20 chairs, **I should think**.
I **can't help thinking** (that) things could have been different.
It was once thought that the sun travelled around the earth.
Well, I like it. What do you think?
What did you think about the idea?
What did you think of the film?
‘Is he any good?’ ‘I don't think so.’
‘Will we make it in time?’ ‘I think so.’
I **think it** highly unlikely that I'll get the job.
She thought him kind and generous.
It was better than I thought possible.
I thought it a good idea to go with him.
He's thought to be one of the richest men in Europe.
I think of this place as my home.
She is thought of as a possible director.
Do you think (that) they’ll come?
I didn't think you liked sports.
Did you honestly think I would agree to that?
I personally think it's all been a lot of fuss over nothing.
I'm inclined to think we've been a little harsh on her.
I still don't know what he really thinks about it.

definitions.definition: to use your mind to consider something, to form connected ideas, to try to solve problems, etc.
definitions.sensetop: think about somethingthink what, how, etc…

examples.text: Are animals able to think?
Let me think *(= give me time before I answer)*.
Stop and think for a moment before making any decisions.
I'm sorry, **I wasn't thinking** *(= said when you have upset or offended somebody accidentally)*.
I can't tell you now—I'll have to **think about it**.
The government needs to **think carefully** about the issues raised.
All he ever thinks about is money.
He was trying to think what to do.
She had thought very deeply about this problem.
He seemed to have lost the ability to think rationally.
She thought long and hard before accepting his offer.
Think about what you are going to do next.

definitions.definition: to have ideas, words or images in your mind
definitions.sensetop: think somethingthink what, how, etc…+ speech

examples.text: You're very quiet. What are you thinking?
I was just thinking what a long way it is.
‘I must be crazy,’ she thought.
‘What can I do now?’ he thought frantically.

definitions.definition: to form an idea of something; to imagine something

examples.text: We couldn't think where you'd gone.
Just think how nice it would be to see them again.
I hate to think what would have happened if we hadn't arrived.
I **like to think** (that) he would help if I needed it.
I can’t think (that) he would be so stupid.
If I'm home late, my mother always thinks the worst.
**Just think**—we'll be lying on the beach this time tomorrow.
Try to **think yourself into** the role.

definitions.definition: to expect something

examples.text: I never thought (that) I’d see her again.
The job took longer than we thought.
You'd think she'd have been grateful for my help *(= but she wasn't)*.
I never thought you would carry out your threat.
Who would have thought to find you here?

definitions.definition: to think in a particular way or on a particular subject

examples.text: Let's think positive.
You need to **think big** *(= aim to achieve a lot)*.
If you want to make money, you've got to think money.

definitions.definition: used in questions to show that you are angry or surprised

examples.text: What do you think you're doing?

definitions.definition: used to make something you say sound less definite or more polite

examples.text: I thought we could go out tonight.
Twenty guests are enough, I would have thought.
**Do you think** you could open the window?
‘You've made a mistake.’ ‘I don't think so.’

definitions.definition: to intend something; to have a plan about something

examples.text: I think I'll go for a swim.
I'm thinking in terms of about 70 guests at the wedding.

definitions.definition: to remember something; to have something come into your mind
definitions.sensetop: think to do somethingthink where, what, etc…

examples.text: I didn't think *(= it did not occur to me)* to tell her.
I can't think where I put the keys.

definitions.definition: to behave in a very confident way that annoys other people, for example by telling them what to do

examples.text: She was acting as if she owned the place.

definitions.definition: used when you suddenly remember something or realize that it might be important

examples.text: Come to think of it, he did mention seeing you.

definitions.definition: used to say that you and another person must both be very clever because you have had the same idea or agree about something
used to say very strongly that you do not agree with something, or that something is not possible

examples.text: Me? Fail? I don't think so.

definitions.definition: used to draw attention to a fact that is not obvious or has not previously been mentioned

examples.text: It was a difficult situation, when you think about it.

definitions.definition: used to say that you hope or believe that something is true

examples.text: I like to think I'm broad-minded.
I’d like to think that you were helping me because you wanted to, not because you felt you had to.

definitions.definition: that is what I expected or suspected

examples.text: ‘He said he'd forgotten.’ ‘I thought as much.’

definitions.definition: used when you are thinking or trying to remember something

examples.text: Now let me see—where did he say he lived?

definitions.definition: to consider it right or acceptable to do something; to decide or choose to do something

examples.text: You must do as you think fit *(= but I don't agree with your decision)*.
The newspaper did not see fit to publish my letter *(= and I criticize it for that)*.

definitions.definition: to say or think bad things about somebody

examples.text: Don't speak ill of the dead.

definitions.definition: to consider a situation again and perhaps change your idea or intention

examples.text: You really should think again about that.

definitions.definition: to say what your thoughts are as you have them
to have a higher opinion of somebody

examples.text: She has behaved appallingly—I must say I thought better of her.

definitions.definition: to decide not to do something after thinking further about it

examples.text: Rosie was about to protest but thought better of it.

definitions.definition: to form your own opinions and make decisions without depending on others
to say or think bad things about somebody

examples.text: I wouldn't want them to think ill of me.

definitions.definition: to consider an activity to be normal and not particularly unusual or difficult

examples.text: She thinks nothing of walking thirty miles a day.

definitions.definition: used as a polite response when somebody has said sorry to you or thanked you
to be able to think and react to things very quickly and effectively without any preparation
to think about something, or how to do something, in a way that is new, different or shows imagination
to think in a clear or logical way

examples.text: The drugs were affecting her and she couldn't think straight.

definitions.definition: to think carefully before deciding to do something

examples.text: You should think twice about employing someone you've never met.

definitions.definition: to have a very good, poor, etc. opinion of somebody/something

examples.text: He thinks the world of his daughter.
I don't think much of her idea.

definitions.definition: used to show that you are surprised or shocked by something

examples.text: To think that my mother wrote all those books and I never knew!

wordOrigin: Old English thencan, of Germanic origin; related to Dutch and German denken.
